There are many CIA secret prisons out there,
known as “Black Sites” and many are still

19.text:
unknown to the public to this day. Here are
some of the worst and most shocking secret

38.text:
Thailand has denied the existence of any secret
prisons, however several leaked reports over

43.text:
the years have suggested the location of Detention
Site Green being somewhere near the province

47.text:
of Udon Thani or just outside of the capital,
Bangkok. Even the CIA themselves admitted

54.text:
to destroying 92 tapes of interviews of terror
suspects that had been safeguarded somewhere

58.text:
in Thailand. One of the detainees of Detention
Site Green was that of Saudi Arabian national,

64.text:
Abu Zubaydah and it is believed that he lost
his left eye as a result of extensive interrogations

69.text:
involving torture conducted by the CIA. During
his time in CIA custody, Zubaydah was waterboarded

77.text:
83 times, so severely to the point of bubbles
rising from his open mouth or vomiting and

84.text:
blacking out. Aside from this, Zubaydah was
also subjected to forced nudity, sleep deprivation

91.text:
and physical assaults. Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri,
one of al-Qaida’s “most skilled” co-ordinators

98.text:
and mastermind behind the bombing of the USS
Cole was also subjected to enhanced interrogation

104.text:
techniques at Detention Site Green, similar
to that of Zubaydah including waterboarding

109.text:
in addition to being threatened with sodomy.
Site Green was shut down in late 2002 and

114.text:
both Zubaydah and Nashiri were transferred
to Poland.

129.text:
What may have seemed like a normal looking
building was actually far from that. This

134.text:
very property, 15 miles outside the capital,
Vilnius, was believed to have been a CIA Black

139.text:
Site, used to interrogate Al-Qaeda suspects
who had been captured in Afghanistan. It was

145.text:
windowless at the time and surrounded by a
metal fence and security cameras. According

150.text:
to human rights activist, John Sifton, the
activities in the prison were illegal, which

154.text:
included various forms of torture, such as
sleep deprivation, forced standing and painful

159.text:
stress positions. The site at Antaviliai was
operational for over a year and during that

165.text:
time, it held at least eight suspected terrorists
within its walls. As of now, the site is being

169.text:
used to train Lithuania’s state security
service.

185.text:
Temara Interrogation Centre, also known as
Temara Secret Detention Centre, is a secret

190.text:
prison facility, located in a forest 9 miles
from the capital, Rabat. The facility has

195.text:
come under heavy scrutiny by non-governmental
organisations such as Amnesty International

199.text:
and Human Rights Watch for their recurrent
and flagrant violation of Human Rights. Detainees

204.text:
had repeatedly been beaten, sexually abused
and sleep deprived. Other reported methods

210.text:
of torture include the suspension of the body
in contorted positions, cigarette burns, electrocution

216.text:
and even rape by the forced insertion objects
such as bottles into the anus. I can see why

221.text:
Amnesty have denounced the place! The first
known detainee was Mohammed Mossadegh Benkhadra

227.text:
in 1985 and since then others such as Ramzi
Binalshibh, an accused plotter of the 9/11

233.text:
attacks have been interrogated at Temara.
To this day, Temara is still active and in

253.text:
Quartz is the code name for a secret CIA interrogation
facility in a northern Polish forest near

258.text:
the village of Stare Kiejkuty. It served as
a Nazi SS output during World War II and currently

265.text:
now serves a facility to question alleged
Al-Qaeda operatives. A BBC report had stated

270.text:
that Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, architect of
the 9/11 attacks, was detained and interrogated

276.text:
in Quartz. He was subjected to frequent waterboarding,
183 times in fact, which caused near drowning,

284.text:
convulsions, vomiting and black-outs. Beside
from waterboarding, mock executions take place

290.text:
and detainees are treated as prisoners of
war; beaten and forced to endure painful stress

295.text:
positions. The torture techniques were so
extreme that it led to the firing of two top

316.text:
The Salt Pit, also known by the code name
“Cobalt” is an isolated CIA Black Site

320.text:
prison located in the north of Afghanistan’s
capital, Kabul. The CIA authorised more than

327.text:
$200,000 for its construction back in June
2002. Prisoners at The Salt Pit are kept in

333.text:
total darkness and isolation and fed poorly
with some even fed rectally. Moreover, detainees

342.text:
are hosed down while shackled with their hands
above their heads naked, humiliated and subject

348.text:
to sleep deprivation. To make matters worse,
prisoners are left cold with insufficient

353.text:
heat and have only a bucket for human waste.
Loud music is reported to play constantly

360.text:
too. The first detainee at The Salt Pit in
2002 was identified by the CIA as Osama Bin

366.text:
Laden’s former bodyguard, Ridha al-Najjar
who was described as “a broken man” after

372.text:
his experiences at the prison. Najjar was
kept shackled and hooded, suspended with his

378.text:
wrists handcuffed to an overhead bar that
would not allow him to lower his arms. Najjar

383.text:
was also left cold and fed poor quality food
and was even forced to wear a nappy having

390.text:
no access to toilet facilities. In an article,
The Salt Pit was described as “the CIA’s

396.text:
Sadistic Dungeon” as Gul Rahman, an alleged
Afghan militant, died during his stay there

404.text:
from freezing to death. He was buried in an
unmarked grave and his friends and family

409.text:
were never told of what happened to him. No
CIA officers were charged with the crimes

414.text:
relating to Rahman’s death and instead it
was quite the opposite. The CIA officer who

420.text:
ordered Rahman be chained up was given a $2,500
bonus for “consistently superior work.”
